questions.text: Which Article of the Indian Constitution deals with the abolition of untouchability?
questions.explanation: Article 17 of the Indian Constitution abolishes untouchability and prohibits its practice in any form.

questions.text: The Right to Constitutional Remedies is available under which Article?
questions.explanation: Article 32 provides the Right to Constitutional Remedies. It empowers the Supreme Court to issue writs.

questions.text: Which of the following Fundamental Rights can be suspended during a national emergency?
questions.explanation: Article 33 allows suspension of Right to Constitutional Remedies during national emergency.

questions.text: The concept of 'Welfare State' is reflected in which part of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: The Directive Principles of State Policy (Part IV) embody the concept of a Welfare State.

questions.text: Which Article provides for the establishment of the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC)?
options: No specific article; it's established by Parliament's law
questions.explanation: The NHRC is not specifically provided for in the Constitution. It was established under the Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993.

questions.text: The concept of 'Judicial Review' in the Indian Constitution is based on:
options: Implied powers derived from the structure and spirit of the Constitution
Common law tradition inherited from British system
questions.explanation: Judicial Review is primarily based on Article 13, which declares that laws inconsistent with fundamental rights are void.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a Fundamental Right under the Indian Constitution?
options: Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression
questions.explanation: Right to Property was removed from the list of Fundamental Rights by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978.

questions.text: The preamble of the Indian Constitution declares India as a:
questions.explanation: The Preamble was amended by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976 to add the words 'Socialist' and 'Secular'.

questions.text: Who can remove the President of India from office?
options: Both Houses of Parliament by impeachment
questions.explanation: The President can be removed through impeachment as per Article 61.

questions.text: The term of office of a Judge of the Supreme Court is:
questions.explanation: As per Article 124(2), Supreme Court judges hold office until they attain the age of 65 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of the Lok Sabha?
options: Members are nominated by the President
It has a fixed tenure of 5 years
Members are not bound by party whip on all matters
questions.explanation: The Lok Sabha has a maximum tenure of 5 years but can be dissolved earlier.

questions.text: The Rajya Sabha can reject a Money Bill:
options: The Rajya Sabha cannot reject a Money Bill
questions.explanation: As per Article 109(3), the Rajya Sabha can only recommend amendments to a Money Bill. It cannot reject it.

questions.text: Who among the following appoints the Comptroller and Auditor General of India?
questions.explanation: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) is appointed by the President of India on the recommendation of the Prime Minister.

questions.text: The concept of 'Collective Responsibility' of the Cabinet means:
options: Each minister is individually responsible for their actions
The Cabinet collectively takes responsibility for all government actions
Only the PM is responsible for Cabinet actions
Individual ministers are not answerable to Parliament
questions.explanation: Collective Responsibility (Article 75) means the entire Cabinet is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha.

questions.text: Under which Article can the President dissolve the Lok Sabha?
questions.explanation: Article 85(2)(b) empowers the President to dissolve the Lok Sabha.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a power of the President?
questions.explanation: The President cannot declare martial law. Martial law is not recognized under the Indian Constitution.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Preamble is correct?
options: It is a legally binding part of the Constitution
It is just an introduction and not legally binding
It can be amended without following Article 368
It was not part of the original Constitution
questions.explanation: The Preamble is a binding part of the Constitution and can be invoked in courts (Kesavananda Bharati case).

questions.text: The 'Doctrine of Colorable Legislation' prohibits:
options: The Legislature from doing indirectly what it cannot do directly
The Cabinet from advising the President
questions.explanation: The Doctrine of Colorable Legislation prevents legislatures from circumventing constitutional limitations by using indirect methods.

questions.text: Which Article ensures the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights?
questions.explanation: Article 32 provides the Right to Constitutional Remedies and allows any person to move the Supreme Court directly.

questions.text: The 'Advisory Jurisdiction' of the Supreme Court is provided under:
questions.explanation: Article 143 gives the President the power to refer questions of constitutional law or public importance to the Supreme Court.

questions.text: Which of the following writs is used to prevent a person from acting in an office to which they have not been legally appointed?
questions.explanation: Quo Warranto means 'under what authority' and is used to challenge the authority of a person to hold a public office.

questions.text: The concept of 'Equality before law' is enshrined in:
questions.explanation: Article 14 guarantees equality before law and equal protection of law to all persons.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of the Indian President's power to declare an emergency?
options: The President can declare an emergency without any conditions
The President must be satisfied that the security is threatened and shall act on PM's advice
Parliament cannot revoke an emergency once declared
Emergency suspends all Fundamental Rights immediately
questions.explanation: Under Article 352, the President can declare a national emergency on the advice of the PM and Cabinet.

questions.text: The President's power to grant pardons is provided under:
questions.explanation: Article 72 gives the President the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites, and remissions of punishment.

questions.text: How many members can the President nominate to the Lok Sabha?
questions.explanation: Under Article 331, the President can nominate 2 members from the Anglo-Indian community.

questions.text: The concept of 'Separation of Powers' in the Indian Constitution means:
options: Complete separation of Executive, Legislature, and Judiciary
Clear demarcation of powers with some overlaps for checks and balances
The Executive is superior to the Legislature
The Judiciary is subordinate to the Legislature
questions.explanation: India follows a modified separation of powers with deliberate overlaps for creating checks and balances.

questions.text: Which committee recommends the appointment of judges to the Supreme Court?
questions.explanation: The Supreme Court Collegium system (CJI + 4 senior judges) recommends appointments.

questions.text: The Constituent Assembly was chaired by:
questions.explanation: Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the Chairman of the Constituent Assembly.

questions.text: Which Article provides for the abolition of titles except military and academic honors?
questions.explanation: Article 18 abolishes titles to create equality among citizens.

questions.text: The term 'DPSP' refers to:
questions.explanation: DPSP stands for Directive Principles of State Policy, found in Part IV (Articles 36-51).

questions.text: Which of the following is a Joint Sitting of both Houses of Parliament?
questions.explanation: Article 110 provides for a joint sitting to resolve deadlocks between Houses.

questions.text: The 'Doctrine of Locus Standi' means:
options: A person's legal right to bring a case to court
The location where a case is filed
The statute of limitations for filing a case
The procedure for appealing a case
questions.explanation: Locus Standi refers to a person's legal right to bring a case before the court.

questions.text: Which committee is responsible for redressal of grievances of the public?
questions.explanation: The Public Grievances Committee examines public complaints against government action.

questions.text: The 'Sunset Clause' in a statute means:
options: A clause that provides automatic expiration of the law
A clause that becomes effective at sunset
A clause that prevents sunset-hour crimes
A ceremonial clause in the Constitution
questions.explanation: A Sunset Clause provides for the automatic expiration of a law on a specified date.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a power of the Rajya Sabha?
questions.explanation: The Rajya Sabha cannot originate or pass Money Bills independently.

questions.text: The power to interpret the Constitution vests with:
questions.explanation: The Supreme Court has the ultimate authority to interpret the Constitution.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Fundamental Duties is correct?
options: They are as important as Fundamental Rights
They are legally enforceable like Rights
They are moral obligations without direct legal enforcement
They cannot be modified by Parliament
questions.explanation: Fundamental Duties are moral and patriotic obligations, not directly enforceable in courts.

questions.text: The 'Threshold Test' in the context of Indian Constitution refers to:
options: Minimum percentage of votes for party recognition
Minimum number of members required for a valid session
Criteria for testing a law's constitutionality
Minimum age for holding public office
questions.explanation: The Threshold Test is used by courts to determine if a law violates constitutional provisions.

questions.text: How many times has the Indian Constitution been amended?
questions.explanation: As of January 2025, the Indian Constitution has been amended 108 times.

questions.text: Which Amendment introduced the concept of Fundamental Duties?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment (1976) introduced Part IV-A containing Fundamental Duties.

questions.text: The 'Basic Structure' doctrine was established in which landmark case?
options: Shankari Prasad v. Union of India
Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Minerva Mills v. Union of India
questions.explanation: The Kesavananda Bharati case (1973) established the Basic Structure Doctrine.

questions.text: Which of the following is recognized as the 'basic structure' of the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The Basic Structure includes supremacy, democracy, republicanism, secularism, etc.

questions.text: The concept of 'Federalism' in the Indian Constitution is reflected in:
options: The existence of Union and State governments
Division of powers between Union and States
questions.explanation: Indian federalism has two main elements: Division of powers and existence of distinct Union/State governments.

questions.text: Which Article deals with the 'Union and its Territory'?
questions.explanation: Article 1 defines India as a 'Union of States'.

questions.text: Which of the following can be the basis for creating a new state?
options: Linguistic, geographical, or cultural considerations (at Parliament's discretion)
questions.explanation: Parliament has discretion in deciding criteria for new states (Article 3).

questions.text: The 'Residuary Powers' vest with:
questions.explanation: Article 248 grants residuary powers (over subjects not enumerated in any list) to the Union.

questions.text: Which of the following subjects falls under the 'Concurrent List'?
questions.explanation: Education is in the Concurrent List (List III).

questions.text: The 'Ashoka Chakra' in the Indian flag represents:
options: The historical wheel of Emperor Ashoka
questions.explanation: The Ashoka Chakra represents the Dharmachakra (wheel of law), signifying perpetual motion and justice.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of a parliamentary democracy?
options: Head of State is separate from Head of Government
Executive is responsible to the Legislature
questions.explanation: Parliamentary democracy features both a separate Head of State and an Executive responsible to the Legislature.

questions.text: The Indian Constitution can be amended by which procedure?
options: 2/3 majority in both Houses + Ratification by half the state legislatures (for specific provisions)
Options 2 and 3 depending on the amendment
questions.explanation: Article 368 provides for amendment, with stricter requirements for provisions affecting federal structure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of the removal of a judge from the Supreme Court?
options: Impeachment motion → Investigation committee → Report → Vote in both Houses
Investigation committee → Impeachment motion → Report → Vote
Impeachment motion → Report → Investigation → Vote in both Houses
Vote in both Houses → Investigation → Report → Impeachment
questions.explanation: The correct sequence for removing a judge involves a motion signed by MPs, investigation by a committee, a report, and then voting in both Houses.

questions.text: The concept of 'Statutory Interpretation' in Indian law means:
options: Courts interpret statutes to give effect to Parliamentary intent
Statutes are always literal without interpretation
Only Parliament can interpret its own statutes
questions.explanation: Statutory Interpretation is the process by which courts determine the meaning and application of statutes to effectuate Parliamentary intent.

questions.text: Which of the following amendments is related to the 'Right to Education'?
questions.explanation: The 86th Amendment (2002) made Right to Education a Fundamental Right under Article 21-A.

questions.text: The concept of 'Preventive Detention' is allowed under which article?
questions.explanation: Article 22 provides safeguards against preventive detention, such as informing grounds and advisory board review.

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'Non-Justiciable Right'?
questions.explanation: Rights under DPSP (like Right to work, Article 41) are non-justiciable and cannot be directly enforced in courts.

questions.text: The 'Rule of Law' concept in the Indian Constitution means:
options: All laws must be followed without question
No person is above law; everyone is equal before law
questions.explanation: Rule of Law implies that no person is above the law and all are subject to it (Articles 14-16).

questions.text: Which of the following can amend the Constitution through a special procedure?
options: Parliament with state ratification for certain provisions
questions.explanation: Article 368 requires ratification from half the states for amendments affecting federal structure.

questions.text: The 'Doctrine of Pleasure' in Indian context means:
options: A government servant holds office at the pleasure of the President
questions.explanation: Doctrine of Pleasure generally means civil servants hold office at the President's pleasure, subject to constitutional safeguards.

questions.text: Which committee is responsible for formulating rules for Parliamentary procedures?
options: Committee on Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business
questions.explanation: The Committee on Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business formulates rules for the House.

questions.text: The 'Doctrine of Legitimate Expectations' in Administrative Law means:
options: Citizens can expect anything from government
Government must fulfill all expectations of citizens
Government decisions must be consistent with reasonable expectations of affected persons
Only Cabinet members have legitimate expectations
questions.explanation: Legitimate Expectations Doctrine protects citizens when government promises create reasonable expectations.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct definition of 'Delegated Legislation'?
options: Legislation made by persons to whom Parliament has delegated power
questions.explanation: Delegated Legislation refers to laws/rules made by the Executive under powers granted by Parliament.

questions.text: The concept of 'Sub Judice' in parliamentary procedures means:
options: A matter can be discussed in Parliament freely
A matter under judicial consideration cannot be discussed in Parliament
Judges can participate in parliamentary discussions
questions.explanation: Sub Judice rule prevents Parliament from discussing matters currently under judicial consideration.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a power of the Speaker of Lok Sabha?
options: Casting vote in case of tie
Making laws on behalf of Parliament
questions.explanation: The Speaker presides over the House but cannot make laws; that is the function of Parliament.

questions.text: The 'Anti-Defection Law' was introduced through which amendment?
questions.explanation: The 52nd Amendment (1985) added the Tenth Schedule containing the Anti-Defection Law.

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes 'Judicial Review' in the Indian system?
options: Review of judicial orders by higher courts
Review of executive and legislative actions for constitutionality
Review of administrative decisions by administrative authorities
Review of court judgments by legal experts
questions.explanation: Judicial Review allows courts to examine if legislative/executive actions violate the Constitution.

questions.text: The 'Pipe Line Doctrine' in Indian constitutional law refers to:
options: Rights under old laws continue even after new laws are passed
Cases pending in court before a constitutional amendment continue under old law
Government pipelines cannot be interfered with
questions.explanation: The Pipeline Doctrine relates to pending cases continuing under old laws post-amendment (with exceptions).

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of a 'Money Bill'?
options: It deals with appropriation of revenues and financial matters
All of the above are characteristics
questions.explanation: Money Bills (Article 110) deal with taxation, expenditure, and government finances, certified by the Speaker.

questions.text: The 'Doctrine of Proportionality' requires that:
options: All laws must be proportionate to each other
Restriction on rights must be proportionate to the purpose
Proportional representation must be maintained in all elections
Government expenditure must be proportionate to revenue
questions.explanation: Proportionality requires restrictions on rights to be proportionate to the legitimate state objective.

questions.text: Which of the following can challenge a constitutional amendment in court?
options: No one can challenge a constitutional amendment
questions.explanation: Citizens can challenge amendments if they violate the Basic Structure (Kesavananda Bharati case).

questions.text: The concept of 'Cabinet Government' means:
options: The collective executive responsible to the Legislature
A body that makes recommendations to the PM
An administrative committee appointed by judges
questions.explanation: Cabinet Government implies the executive is collectively responsible to the Legislature.

questions.text: Which of the following amendments abolished the upper houses of state legislatures?
questions.explanation: The 65th Amendment authorized abolition of Legislative Councils in states.

questions.text: The 'Emergency Provisions' in the Constitution can be invoked in case of:
questions.explanation: Constitution provides for National (Art 352), State (Art 356), and Financial (Art 360) emergencies.

questions.text: Which article defines the executive power of the President?
questions.explanation: Article 53 vests the executive power of the Union in the President.

questions.text: The concept of 'Concurrent Jurisdiction' means:
options: Only one court can hear a case
Multiple courts can hear the same case
Both civil and criminal courts can hear a matter
Courts can hear matters concurrently with Parliament
questions.explanation: Concurrent Jurisdiction means different courts (e.g., civil and criminal) can deal with relevant aspects of a matter.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about 'Writs' in the Indian Constitution?
options: Only the Supreme Court can issue writs
Only the High Court can issue writs
Both Supreme Court and High Courts can issue writs
Writs can only be issued by the President
questions.explanation: Both SC (Art 32) and High Courts (Art 226) can issue writs.

questions.text: The 'Collegium System' for judicial appointments was established after which case?
questions.explanation: The Second Judges Case (1993) established the Collegium System for judicial independence.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT included in the Fundamental Duties?
options: Provide free education to all children
questions.explanation: Providing free education is a DPSP; it is not listed as an individual citizen's Fundamental Duty.

questions.text: The 'Principle of Natural Justice' in administrative law includes:
options: Audi Alteram Partem (hear the other side)
Nemo Judex in Causa Sua (no one is judge in own cause)
questions.explanation: Natural Justice includes fair hearing (Audi Alteram Partem) and no bias (Nemo Judex).

questions.text: Which amendment introduced 'Panchayati Raj' institutions in the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The 73rd Amendment (1992) introduced Panchayati Raj institutions.

questions.text: The 'Right to Information' under RTI Act can be sought by:
questions.explanation: The RTI Act 2005 allows 'any person' to seek information.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes 'Impeachment'?
options: It is formal charge by legislature
Impeachment is the charge, not the removal
Only the President can be impeached
questions.explanation: Impeachment is the formal charge/accusation; removal follows conviction.

questions.text: The concept of 'Supremacy of Constitution' means:
options: Constitution is highest law of the land
No law can be contrary to Constitution
questions.explanation: Constitutional Supremacy means it is the highest law and no other law can contradict it.

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'Private Member's Bill'?
options: Bill introduced by a private company
Bill introduced by a member who is not a minister
Bill that affects only private citizens
questions.explanation: A Private Member's Bill is introduced by an MP who is not a minister.

questions.text: The 'Doctrine of Repugnancy' in Indian federalism means:
options: Central law is always superior to state law
State law is independent of central law
When concurrent subject laws conflict, Union law prevails
Laws must always be identical in all states
questions.explanation: Repugnancy means in case of conflict on concurrent subjects, Union law prevails (Art 254).

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct definition of 'Ultra Vires'?
options: Beyond the powers; exceeding constitutional/legal authority
questions.explanation: Ultra Vires means 'beyond the powers' or exceeding authority.

questions.text: The 'Question Hour' in Parliament is designed to:
questions.explanation: Question Hour holds the executive accountable by allowing MPs to question ministers.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the 'Tenth Schedule'?
options: It deals with Union and State relations
questions.explanation: The Tenth Schedule (52nd Amendment) contains the anti-defection law.

questions.text: The 'Proviso' in a constitutional article means:
options: An exception or qualification to a rule
A provision that can be repealed
questions.explanation: A Proviso is a clause that provides an exception or qualification to the main provision.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a criterion for disqualification under the anti-defection law?
options: Abstaining from voting against party decision
questions.explanation: Criticizing party policies is part of free speech and not grounds for disqualification.

questions.text: The concept of 'Quorum' in Parliament means:
options: Minimum number of members required for valid proceedings
questions.explanation: Quorum is the minimum number of members (1/10th) required for valid proceedings.

questions.text: Which article deals with the appointment of the Attorney General of India?
questions.explanation: Article 76 provides for the appointment of the Attorney General of India.

questions.text: The 'Lame Duck' period in the context of government means:
options: When government is too weak to function
Period after election defeat but before new government takes office
Period when government has lost majority support
questions.explanation: Lame Duck period is the time between election defeat and the new government assuming office.

questions.text: Which of the following is a 'Justiciable' right?
questions.explanation: Right to Education (Article 21-A) is a Fundamental Right and thus justiciable.

questions.text: The 'Swadeshi' principle in DPSP aims to promote:
questions.explanation: DPSP promotes policies encouraging domestic production and self-reliance (Swadeshi spirit).

questions.text: Which of the following amendments is related to 'Reservations for Other Backward Classes'?
questions.explanation: The 103rd Amendment (2019) provided for EWS reservation, modifying Articles 15 & 16.

questions.text: The concept of 'Parity of reasoning' in constitutional interpretation means:
options: Similar facts should receive similar treatment
Reasoning must be written in simple language
Court reasoning must match government reasoning
questions.explanation: Parity of Reasoning ensures consistency by treating similar facts similarly.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct composition of the Union Public Service Commission?
questions.explanation: UPSC comprises a Chairman and 10 members (Article 316).

questions.text: The 'Doctrine of Necessities' in constitutional law allows:
options: Government to ignore constitutional provisions in emergencies
Government to take necessary action in crisis without pre-existing law
questions.explanation: Doctrine of Necessities permits necessary emergency actions for state survival without prior legislative authority.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of the Indian judicial system that ensures independence?
questions.explanation: Fixed tenure is a key constitutional guarantee for judicial independence.

questions.text: The 'Positive Discrimination' allowed under the Constitution means:
options: All discrimination is allowed if justified
Discrimination against privileged groups to help disadvantaged groups
questions.explanation: Positive Discrimination (affirmative action) helps disadvantaged groups to achieve substantive equality.
